data.title: Add Michael Caine to the List of Actors Refusing to Work with Woody Allen
data.meta_description: Caine won an Oscar for starring in the Allen film Hannah and Her Sisters, but he says he would not make another Allen movie.
data.text:
The list of actors refusing to work with Woody Allen is getting longer—and more prestigious. In a recent interview with The Guardian, Oscar winner Michael Caine declared that he was done working with the director, specifically because of Dylan Farrow’s allegations against Allen. (Allen’s estranged daughter claims that the director sexually abused her as a child; Allen has repeatedly denied the claims.) Caine now joins stars like Greta Gerwig, Colin Firth, and Rachel Brosnahan, all of whom have worked with the award-winning filmmaker before, and have since vowed to never work with him again.

“I am so stunned,” Caine said when asked directly about the allegations. “I’m a patron of the N.S.P.C.C. [the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children] and have very strong views about pedophilia. I can’t come to terms with it, because I loved Woody and had a wonderful time with him. I even introduced him to Mia [Farrow]. I don’t regret working with him, which I did in complete innocence; but I wouldn’t work with him again, no.”

Caine starred in Allen’s 1986 film Hannah and Her Sisters, a film that landed him his first Oscar win. (Caine would go on to pick up a second best-supporting-actor statuette in 2000.) As he mentioned, Caine also introduced Allen to the actress Mia Farrow in the late 1970s. Farrow and Allen began dating shortly afterward, and the actress went on to star in several of his films, including Hannah and Her Sisters. The couple decided to adopt Dylan in 1985.

Over the last few years, Dylan has been extremely vocal about the sexual abuse she says she endured during childhood, allegedly perpetrated by Allen. She wrote an essay for The New York Times about it in 2014, and, in the wake of the #MeToo movement, wrote an op-ed for the Los Angeles Times last year, kicking off another wave of industry figures reconsidering Allen. “Why is it that Harvey Weinstein and other accused celebrities have been cast out by Hollywood, while Allen recently secured a multi-million-dollar distribution deal with Amazon?” she wrote.

Farrow also gave her first TV interview about the issue earlier this year, telling CBS This Morning that Allen “has been lying for so long” about the allegations. Allen, meanwhile, denied the claims in a robust statement which said, in part, that “even though the Farrow family is cynically using the opportunity afforded by the Time’s Up movement to repeat this discredited allegation, that doesn’t make it any more true today than it was in the past,” he wrote. “I never molested my daughter—as all investigations concluded a quarter of a century ago.”

Still, the post-Weinstein era, coupled with Farrow’s repeated claims, have inspired quite a few actors to distance themselves from Allen. Stars like Timothée Chalamet and Rebecca Hall recently donated their salaries from Allen’s last film to organizations like Time’s Up, essentially apologizing for working with the controversial filmmaker. And now Caine is joining the chorus.
